title: (x) Flatbush Avenue Health Center - American Uncial (Celtic Bold) {Mike Y, Jan Sandvik}
content:
It's been stretched, squooshed and badly redrawn, but does anyone know what typeface this signage was derived from? My first guess was Albertus, but it lacks a wedge atop the A, for instance.   
   
 ![Flatbush_logo.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125202058im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/22709.jpg)
author: marcox

comments.content:
Holland Title looks promising, although I can't find a decent sample of it online.   
   
 [http://www.fonts.com/findfonts/detail.asp?pid=205066](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125202058/http:/www.fonts.com/findfonts/detail.asp?pid=205066)   
   
And that S looks straight out of an uncial.

I think Marc hit it when he said uncial. Look at [Neue Hammer Uncial](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125202058/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/neue-hammer-unziale/)'s caps. (BTW, some books show this as American Uncial (Mecanorma), but Myfonts selections with that name are true uncials, without these caps.)

Try freeware font "Celtic Bold" from this page   
   
 [http://www.moorstation.org/fontennium/celtic/fscelt1.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125202058/http:/www.moorstation.org/fontennium/celtic/fscelt1.htm)
Many thanks, Typophilers. It's fun to be on the receiving end of an ID!

Dueling font ID's. Not so fast. I still think that Yves was right about Celtic Bold. Here is American Uncial Bold (ICG) -- one Grant should recognize -- credited to Oldstyle in the Image Club catalog from my old Letterpress Collection. It came in 6 weights including open and Initials, with regular and bold weights of each.   
 ![American Uncial ICG](http://web.archive.org/web/20051125202058im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/22721.gif)
Mike, that's a good one, Celtic Bold is definitely a rip-off from American Uncial Bold.
